fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
This week we discussed specifics of weakening along overlapping cycles, and trade-offs of our two proposed approaches:
Defining weakening and unfolding as reductions in their own right.
Only do weakening and unfolding as part of a "hereditary" substitution used in \Rightarrow and \forall reduction.
The idea is that we push the cycle "a single rule up". Notice that the subtree \Sigma is copied in its entirety. This clearly simplifies when the rule above the companion has a single premise.

In order to propagate a weakening along any cycle, we can interleave unrollings and weakening reductions:
If a weakening is directly under the companion for a "bad" cycle, we make sure to unroll that "bad" cycle first before unrolling any others!
If a weakening is directly under the companion for any single cycle, then we unroll that cycle one step, and push the weakening up one step. The "good"-ness of the cycle with respect to the weakening instance is, in this setup, only used to decide which cycle to unroll first when reaching a companion for multiple cycles.

Reuben made a point that we need to be careful when weakening away labels and reintroducing them that no name clashes occur. We decided to adopt something that seems like a variant of Barendregt's variable convention - essentially, newly introduced labels and formula variables are considered fresh with respect to the entire proof below the rule instance that introduces them.

I wonder if nested cycles make this more complicated: if a weakening is good with respect to the "top-most" cycle, can you guarantee that it is good for any "sub-cycles" in the subproof above the companion? I have a feeling that you can guarantee this (Edit: you probably cannot guarantee this).

It also seems that if you start with a cyclic proof where weakenings are only used immediately after buds, then they will always be good with respect to any cycles that might be produced via unfolding. We need to prove that this is the case.

Objectives after this meeting:
Define weakening reduction, taking it to be stuck at a companion if the weakening is not good w.r.t. the cycle(s) corresponding to that companion. Pay extra care to possiblility of nested cycles, and also we should assume CNF as it looks like some of our intutions are based on taking it as given.
Define other reductions on "weakening normal forms", making sure that "good-ness of weakenings" is preserved by these.
Show that a proof where weakening rules are only used below buds doesn't get stuck in any reduction sequence.
